Award.AwardTitle: HBCU-RISE: Enhancement of Research Infrastructure for the Development of Nanoelectromechanical Systems (NEMS) Devices and Materials

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With National Science Foundation support, Norfolk State University will strengthen the institution's research infrastructure and facilitate implementation of a doctoral program in Materials Science and Engineering in the Center for Materials Research. The project supports the development of enhanced research capabilities and curricular modifications in the area of Nanoelectromechanical Systems (NEMS) Devices and Materials for biomedical applications. Support is provided to train Ph.D. students, especially underrepresented minorities, in these emerging fields through the enhancement of the curriculum to include nanoelectromechanical systems - related content, professional development activities for students and post-doctoral researchers, the acquisition of equipment to facilitate the proposed research, and engagement of K-12 students in STEM activities.

Intellectual Merit:
The project supports research on the processing of Nanoelectromechanical Systems materials and devices for biomedical applications. Efforts include the development of plasmonic nano-array biosensors, mechanically tunable hyperbolic meta-surfaces, and nano-cantilever biosensor arrays; and studies of electrochemicalmechanical coupling of 3-D nanoelectrodes in neural sensing. Through this project, new generation label-free biosensors will be realized via Surface-Enhanced Raman Scattering substrates incorporated with curved graphene structures. Moreover, NEMS cantilever resonator arrays will be developed and integrated with biocompatible nano-materials and multiple monoclonal antibodies to improve the sensitivity and specificity of prostate cancer screening.

Broader Impacts:
The project will enhance the Materials Science Curricula at Norfolk State University to include emerging topics such as Nanoelectromechanical Systems. The expansion of research capabilities will be facilitated, improving the recruitment and retention of quality doctoral students and faculty, and strengthening partnerships with universities and industry. By exposing underrepresented minority K-12 students to engaging STEM outreach activities, the pipeline of students in STEM fields will be established, with the ultimate goal of inspiring youth to pursue degrees in STEM fields. This research will lead to an enhanced understanding of nanostructures for novel functionalities such as prostate cancer screening. The research will also lead to improved electrochemical sensing electrode designs, increasing the lifetime of implantable biomedical sensing devices and reducing the cost of disease diagnostics and health care.

ProgramElement.Text: Centers for Rsch Excell in S&T

ProgramReference.Text: CENTERS FOR RSCH EXCELL IN S&T

POR.DRECONTENT:
This RISE project significantly enhanced research capabilities and infrastructure for the development and processing of Nanoelectromechanical Systems (NEMS) materials and devices. This RISE grant has also supported education and training programs for graduate students from Materials Science and Engineering MS and PhD programs and Electronics Engineering MS program.  The acquisition of equipment including on excimer laser, an EMI shielding faraday cage and high precision electrical characterization tools and supporting service contract of electron-beam lithography (EBL) system, researches for NEMS materials and devices were highly facilitated. Particularly EBL system has produced excellent results in fabrication of NEMS devices for energy and biomedical sensing applications. 

HBCU-RISE team produced remarkable contributions to new fields of NEMS research including the development of neural sensing and imaging devices, plasmonic nano-array biosensors, mechanically tunable hyperbolic meta-surfaces, and studies of electrochemical-mechanical coupling of 3-D nanoelectrodes. As one of outstanding outcomes, we thoroughly investigated the effect of electrochemical and mechanical coupling in neurochemical sensing and developed an experimental model to validate the numerical models. We also developed nanoelectrodes for in-depth monitoring of fast brain activity with the use of Electrical Impedance Tomography. This research outcome enables successful imaging and reconstruction of brain activity. Also, mechanically soft and flexible nano-sensing electrode arrays were investigated to relieve mechanical strain and stress on the brain tissue. Throughout the project period, the RISE investigator continuously developed collaborative research with other investigators in external research institutions and enhanced the reputation and research competitiveness of NSU through increased scholarly achievement of faculty and students in conducting cutting edge research and publishing of research results. The intellectual achievements during this funding period include a range of significant publications over 20 journal papers, which were fully or partially supported by HBCU-RISE, in high impact journals including Nature Materials and others (Scientific Reports, Biosensors, Advanced Functional Materials, Applied Physic Letter, etc.). 

The NSU RISE program coordinated training and professional development for students over the entire project years. The RISE has continuously provided support for students to present their research at technical conferences and to attend professional organization conferences to seek employment opportunities. The enhancement of graduate curriculum and professional development activities for graduate students increased scholarly achievement and facilitated their carrier development and job placements in frontend nanotechnology companies including the Intel and the Boston Scientific. 

The broader impact of the research infrastructure enhancement and development for the Ph.D. program in Materials Science and Engineering (MSE) at NSU is the education and training of a new generation of minority scientists and engineers in the emerging area of Nanoelectromechanical Systems (NEMS) materials and devices for biomedical applications. This RISE project also provided many outreach activities to engage K-12 students in various types of nanotechnology learning and experiences. Outreach to the community, especially to the local high schools, has been a core value of the NSU RISE Center. In the project years, RISE created a system to facilitate the offering of events on and off campus for all projects, including leveraging of efforts across projects. The availability of a library of kits, with accompanying documentation, and the implementation of an online system for graduate students participation in outreach events under the auspices of this RISE project has greatly facilitated the delivery of events. As part of training for graduate students to communicate science to broader audiences, Materials Science and Engineering graduate students delivered many science outreach events to all four Norfolk high schools reaching over 200 students per year, including a large number of African Americans.


Last Modified: 03/31/2019
Modified by: Hargsoon Yoon
